Look, I think - I think the President is - is bitter, and he's got reason to be bitter, and - and angry. I think Nancy Pelosi is bitter and - and angry as well because she - the impeachment was an absolute disaster. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb16', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb16', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } Put aside the rhetoric, just the objective measures. The Gallup poll that came out, when in October, before the - when the impeachment inquiry started, 39 percent approval for Donald Trump, today, 49 percent in Gallup, the highest he's ever had, so a 10-point rise in approval as the hearings, as the trial, was taking place. The people who said he shouldn't be removed from Office were 46 percent at the start, they're now 52 percent. His - the number of people who think--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: THIESSEN
utterances.sentences: --that he should get a second term has risen from 41 to - to 50 percent. And he, by the way, 94 percent support in the GOP compared to what Obama had around this time, which was--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: THIESSEN
utterances.sentences: --in the high 70s.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: No, these numbers are very good. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: THIESSEN
utterances.sentences: You know, he's--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: There's - there's no - there's no doubt about that.

utterances.speaker: THIESSEN
utterances.sentences: It's - it's been an absolute disaster for the Democrats.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Let me just play this from the - from President Trump today in the speech as well. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: If they find that I happen to walk across the street, and maybe go against a light or something, "Let's impeach him!" if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: So, we'll probably have to do it again because these people have gone stone-cold crazy. But I've beaten them all my life. And I'll beat them again if I have to.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Richard, is there - is there exhaustion on the side of Democrats for this effort? And is there - is there a feeling that it would be more productive to not keep going with all these investigations?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Listen, that's a very - that argument's very - I sympathize with that argument. I think there's some truth to that. I think with that being said, for this President, to compare - compare what happened with his call with the Ukrainians, to him crossing the street, is a little bit like comparing apples and oranges here. There was definitely some wrongdoing in this call. I think even a lot of Republicans will admit that, right? Did it lead - was it impeachable? Did it get it - to get him out of Office?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Or should it have ever gotten to that-- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: No, it did not.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: --to this whole process--

utterances.speaker: THIESSEN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: --is a very legitimate question.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Well I think there comes a time--

utterances.speaker: THIESSEN
utterances.sentences: That's exactly right.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: There comes a time in every Presidential - every President's career, and every President's sort of legacy, where they say "Now is the time for me to focus on civility. Now is the time for me to focus on being a moral leader." The President haven't found any of those things at this point in time even after being impeached. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: THIESSEN
utterances.sentences: Again--

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: There's no contrition here whatsoever.

utterances.speaker: THIESSEN
utterances.sentences: Richard, she just tore up his State of the Union address on national television.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: But he's still the President of the United States, Marc.

utterances.speaker: THIESSEN
utterances.sentences: Don't - don't lecture us about civility. I mean it--

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: There's one of those.

utterances.speaker: THIESSEN
utterances.sentences: It doesn't matter. That's, you know-- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: This is part of the problem.

utterances.speaker: THIESSEN
utterances.sentences: She - she broke with the protocol.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: You know what? Something--

utterances.speaker: THIESSEN
utterances.sentences: She wouldn't say the word.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: And it does matter.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: In order for that to happen--

utterances.speaker: THIESSEN
utterances.sentences: She would not say the word.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: --the dynamic in some material way has to change. But these two are going to keep going at each other. There's no doubt about it. So, over the next nine months, the focus turns to the election, and we'll see what happens here. Thanks you guys. Good to see you both tonight.

utterances.speaker: THIESSEN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Good to see you, Martha.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So, President Trump today labeling Nancy Pelosi as a horrible person after she doubled down on tearing his speech at the State of the Union address. Speaker Pelosi's daughter, Christine, will respond for the first time coming up next.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I had - I had Nancy Pelosi sitting four seats away, and I'm saying things that a lot of people wouldn't have said, but I meant every--

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: --I meant every word of it.

utterances.speaker: N. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: I tore up a manifesto of mistruths. And I don't need any lessons from anybody, especially President of the United States about dignity. I think it was completely entirely appropriate.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: The ongoing feud between President Trump and Nancy Pelosi boiling over today. The two traded war barbs through the media. They have not spoken in months. And there doesn't appear to be any thaw coming. President Trump blasted Nancy Pelosi during the National Prayer Breakfast, held up a newspaper heralding his acquittal, as Speaker - as the Speaker of the House sat just feet away - feet away. And later, at a celebratory speech in the East Room of the President - of the White House, I should say, the President took aim once again.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Nancy Pelosi is a horrible person. And she wanted to impeach a long time ago. When she said, "I pray for the President. I pray for the President." She doesn't pray. She may pray, but she prays for the opposite.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: But I doubt she prays at all.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: All right, here now exclusively, Christine Pelosi, the daughter of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, and the Author of "The Nancy Pelosi Way." Christine, thank you for being here tonight. CHRISTINE PELOSI, AUTHOR, "THE NANCY PELOSI WAY": Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: You know, I think, first of all, I just want to get your reaction. When you saw the Speaker rip up those pages, very intentionally, you know, one, two, three, in front of the cameras, what was your reaction? Did you know she was going to do that?

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: No idea she was going to do that. I think Nancy Pelosi is a wonderful person. I know she prays daily, including for the President, including for the country, as we've talked before. And in watching that, her reaction to that speech, I thought to myself, "That's an Italian grandma move." I saw my grandmother do that years ago, in her kitchen, when there was a guest who had been at my grandfather's house, very rude to him, she just simply picked up the person's plate, without comment, went into the kitchen. We heard a little crashing sound. She threw the plate away, came back, sat down, didn't say another word. So, to me, I thought that's--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: You thought it was appropriate?

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: --that's an Italian grand - well I thought it was an--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: --an Italian grandma move. I think that's--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So, she said - she said it was the most courteous thing.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: --that was her reaction to it. She didn't say anything.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: She said it was the most - let me ask you--

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: She didn't, you know.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: --the most courteous thing I could do, she said, given my other exuberances. What did she mean? What were her other exuberances? What would have been worse than that?

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: Well I think plenty of things would have been worse than that. I mean, for example, he could have put his outstretched hand towards her, and she could have refused to shake it, which surprised me when I first watched the speech, I thought "Well wait, where - her hand's out there. Why isn't he shaking her hand?" When you hear someone give a speech, in front of you, and say things that you know to be untrue, he says he's protecting people's care, and I know Kellyanne Conway just repeated that, but the fact of the matter is he's in court suing to overturn the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. He is in court trying to uphold rules that will - that will change that - just did that will change the definition of a public charge that will hurt immigrants like his own father who came in--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Well they have policy differences. There's no doubt about that.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: --who needed that. Well but if you lie about--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: But let me ask you this. But, Christine?

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: --what the--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: --what the - what you're doing, that's not a policy--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: That - you know what?

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: --difference. That's a lie.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I have watched State of the Union addresses my whole life, as I know you have too.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: I've been there.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: There are always Presidents who stand up there, and who talk about their policies. There are always people in the audience, including Speakers of the House of op - of the opposite Party, who don't agree that they are saying what they see as the - the more effective policy. They have different views on the way to fix healthcare in this country. It doesn't mean that you - you rip up the speech. I mean you - generally--

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: It might if you think the person's lying.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: --my whole life, people have sat there respectfully, and listened to each other. That's part of what happens at the State of the Union address. And - and, frankly, you know, I just I - I thought it was surprising. I mean I was with a panel of people, Democrats, Republicans, and - and everybody, you know, thought "Wow! That was - that was a surprising move." And - and that was--

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: It was.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: --one of the nicer words that was used for it.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: Well that was your panel of people. I was with hundreds of people last night, who loved it, and thought, "Thank God. Somebody"--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I'm sure that's true. No, I'm sure.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: --"with the flick of the wrist had some resistance."

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I - I know that sentiment is - is out there as well. I'm just - I'm just saying.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: Oh, it's out there, for sure. Yes, it's has been.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So - so how about this comment?

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: Martha, going to your point though--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: --it's not a matter of saying you and I can disagree.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: We're both speaking the truth. It's a different thing if I say there's a lawsuit to overturn the law, and at the same time, I say I'm defending the law, I am lying.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes, but their lawsuits are--

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: If that - that is - that is a fundamental difference there.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: But their argument is that the - the lawsuit to overturn the law is to - is to allow a system that - that they think would be better to protect people and would provide better coverage in the end because they think that that law is not effective so far in doing so. So that, to me, is a policy difference. It's - it's - "Yes, we're trying to do this because we want to overturn that," and that's a policy difference. I don't - I don't see it as - as lies. But maybe we just have a different way of - of, you know, listening to both sides here. I just want to play this other - this other - this other sound bite here from the Speaker about thinking that the President was sedated. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: N. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: It was also an act of kindness, because I - he looked to me like he was a little sedated. He looked that way last year too. But he didn't want to shake hands. That was that. That meant nothing to me. It had nothing to do with my tearing up.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So, I mean what - I'm just curious, what your take is on that. When I heard that I thought--

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: Well I think--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: --she tell you he was drugged or something?

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: No. I thought - well I think - I actually thought he had a cold this morning. I didn't know what - what - what that remark.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: But maybe he was - maybe had a cold last night too. I actually thought he sounded like he had a cold this morning. But, in any event, I think there's two things. One is I thought you were going to play the part where he said all the things that he said about Mitt Romney's faith, which I thought was bizarre, because I remember in 2012, Mitt Romney talking about his faith quite a lot at the Republican Convention. So, I don't think it was new and I don't think it was a crutch.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well I think a lot of people thought that--

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: Again, going back to--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: --a lot of that back-and-forth was over the line.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: Well - well, again, I think there's a couple of things going on here.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: On both sides.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: First of all, the House of Representatives has the power. If they want to get something passed, they have to go through the House of Representatives. So, sooner or later, he's going to have to go back there. That's how the trade deal - deal got done after the House of Representatives--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: --made it better, working with Labor. You want to get something done on healthcare? You want to get something done on the budget--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: --he will eventually have to go have - back to the House of Representatives to make something happen.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Absolutely true. Let me ask you one--

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: So, we will - we will want to see what - what--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: That's--

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: --what those dynamics are then.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: --very true.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: But it's important to note that when the budget comes out, the numbers don't lie. And so, the numbers are going to have to re - that's where the stark reality is going to be.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: That proof will be in the pudding.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: All right, we'll--

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: If they really want to do something on healthcare and infrastructure, let's look at the budget--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I - I think that's--

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: --and see it's our statement of our values.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: --something that all Americans would like to see happen on both fronts. So, I hope - I hope that's true. One last question for you.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Let's put up this Gallup poll. During the course of impeachment, the President's approval rating went up 10 points. Does that, you know, I mean I think that would lead to some frustration on the part of those who pursued it, for whatever reasons, they pursued it. Does that - what do you think about that?

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: Well a couple of things. I saw that Gallup poll. It's more heavily weighted now towards Republicans than it was before. So, if you look at the breakdown of the numbers, they're different, and that could be where the numbers are. But the people who decided to go forward with the impeachment inquiry and with the impeachment were very, very clear. This isn't about the polls. This is about the truth. This is about finding the truth. And this is about making sure that we say Article Two constrains the President. It doesn't mean he can say he can do whatever he wants. And so, what we're talking about, as we go forward, and listen, our - our voters, they want to hear about healthcare. They want to hear about healthcare. They want to be assured--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: But - but the Speaker of the House said--

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: --that the President is going to be--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: --in the beginning of this process--

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: --following the law.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: --that we shouldn't do impeachment because it will be too divisive. Now, I have to believe she looks at these numbers, and says, "See," to her - to her Caucus, "I told you this was going to be a mistake. And it is. His numbers have gone up during this process."

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: It's not a mistake to stand up for America. It's not a mistake to stand up for the truth. It's not - and again, you're looking at one poll. RealClearPolitics average has him going up one point, not several. Again, you're looking at a weighted poll that has more Republicans in it now--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Well and we aren't choosing (ph)--

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: --than it did two months ago.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: --just rattle through a whole bunch of numbers that - that are - are positive--

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: He did in - in Gallup, yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: --over the course of those three months.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: All in that same weighted polls, so.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: All right, so you don't - OK.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: But - but point is--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: We'll see.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: --whether it is or is - it isn't, the most important poll is going to be on Election Day, November 3rd.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Absolutely, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: And the question is going to be are we going to move forward and have a President, you know, of a different Party, who's going to bring us together, and protect our healthcare, or are we going to have four more years of Donald Trump?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Well, at this point, one thing that we do know--

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: We shall see.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: --is that the people will decide.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: And that will happen in nine months. Christine Pelosi, thank you. We appreciate you coming in. Good to see you tonight.

utterances.speaker: C. PELOSI
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Martha.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So, we'll be right back with more. Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: The AP dropping a bombshell tonight, saying that they will not declare a winner in the Iowa Caucus, due to a tight margin between Pete Buttigieg and Bernie Sanders, and other irregularities in this process. What a fiasco that has been! And 2020 candidate Mike Bloomberg skipped the whole thing altogether. He's also skipping New Hampshire. Instead, he's engineering a nationwide "Weekend of Action" against President Trump with more than 1,200 events, over the course of this weekend, in 30 states. Joining me now exclusively is Michael Nutter, Co-Chairman of the Bloomberg Campaign. Michael, thanks for being here tonight. Good to have you with us.

utterances.speaker: MICHAEL NUTTER, CO-CHAIRMAN, BLOOMBERG CAMPAIGN
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Martha, thank you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So, I want to play a sound bite from Karl Rove on this show about what he thinks needs to happen for your candidate to do well. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: KARL ROVE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: For Bloomberg to win, Biden has to implode in the next two or three weeks. Which means, coming in an embarrassing finish here either, you know, third or fourth and distant from the first place finisher --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ROVE
utterances.sentences: -- and then be creamed in New Hampshire like we expect.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Do you agree? How much does that matter for Mike Bloomberg to campaign?

utterances.speaker: NUTTER
utterances.sentences: Well, it's always interesting when Republicans want to give us advice and perspective about the election. Mike Bloomberg is running against Donald Trump. As you mentioned in your opening, we're running a general election-type campaign through the primary and caucus season. There are a lot of things that will happen during the course of February. And as you mentioned again primarily because of when Mike announced, we are not on the ballot in the four states during the course of February. But super Tuesday and forward, we'll be active and competitive. So, you know, we'll see what happens in -- I mean, they're still obviously trying to figure out --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes. But, I mean, obviously Karl Rove has run a number of successful campaigns by the way --

utterances.speaker: NUTTER
utterances.sentences: Iowa, New Hampshire, and Nevada.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: -- and he was just being asked, you know --

utterances.speaker: NUTTER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: -- if you were the strategist what would you say?

utterances.speaker: NUTTER
utterances.sentences: Yes. I'm not diminishing --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So, no. I just want to ask you.

utterances.speaker: NUTTER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So, he's saying, you know, that for Bloomberg to succeed -- do you still feel that way? Because there was a time when the word was that Mayor Bloomberg wasn't going to get in if Biden was in. But then apparently, you know, he sensed that Biden was maybe weak. Because a lot of people including a lot of Obama supporters had no praise for him whatsoever. So how do you play that now at this point? Biden seems to be hanging in there.

utterances.speaker: NUTTER
utterances.sentences: Well -- of course, he's hanging in there. And he has, you know, support in a variety of places. Mike looked at a set of data as he's a data-driven guy over an extended period of time, plus, you know, the day it started last summer and decided based on the information he had available that he was concerned as to whether any of the present candidates at that time could beat Donald Trump in the general election. That's the -

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: NUTTER
utterances.sentences: -- obviously, you had to get through primaries and caucuses. But the general election really is the Super Bowl of this particular contest and decided that he owed it to, you know, the country personally to actively get involved, use his resources and put together a campaign unlike anything that anyone has seen, certainly in modern times.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Well, he's -- I mean, it's very interesting. Because in the national polls he's in fourth place right now.

utterances.speaker: NUTTER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So, he's been moving up to double digits which is impressive for somebody who's not in yet.

utterances.speaker: NUTTER
utterances.sentences: Yes. Third, fourth. Depending on which poll you look at.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I'd like to play this from Bernie Sanders on the campaign trail today.

utterances.speaker: SEN. BERNIE SANDERS, I-VT., PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: And now suddenly a guy comes in who does not campaign one bit in Iowa, New Hampshire, he's not on the ballot. I guess in Nevada or South Carolina. But he's worth $55 billion. And I guess if you're worth $55 billion, you can get the rules changed.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So, I imagine that's a sentiment that is going to be thrown at him quite a bit, Michael. What do you say?

utterances.speaker: NUTTER
utterances.sentences: Well, the fact of the matter, Martha, and I'm sure you have reported on this, the fact of the matter is that the DNC from the start always indicated to the candidates at that time, last year, that there would be a series of either escalating or changing criteria or thresholds. The fact of the matter is, I believe there have been at least four, possibly five different rules changes depending on --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's true.

utterances.speaker: NUTTER
utterances.sentences: -- which debate you're talking about, July, August, September, October, November, December, and even January.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: NUTTER
utterances.sentences: All along the way, there have been various changes in the rules --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: NUTTER
utterances.sentences: -- thresholds, money amounts, 20 states, et cetera, et cetera. This is not being done for --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: All right. I got to go.

utterances.speaker: NUTTER
utterances.sentences: -- or to benefit Mike Bloomberg. That's a nice narrative but it's just not true.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: All right. Well, we'll be watching. Michael, thanks a lot for being here. We appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: NUTTER
utterances.sentences: Sure. Thanks.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Trey Gowdy is coming up next. Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: President Trump today had a searing rebuke of former FBI director James Comey.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Had I not fired James Comey, who was a disaster, by the way, it's possible I wouldn't even be standing here right now. We caught him in the act. Dirty cops. Bad people. They were going to try and overthrow the government of the United States. A duly elected president. If I didn't fire James Comey, we would have never found this stuff. Because when I fired that sleazebag, all hell broke out.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Interesting moment from today. Joining me now, Trey Gowdy. He's the former House oversight committee chairman and now a Fox News contributor. Trey, good to have you with us today.

utterances.speaker: TREY GOWDY, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: Thanks, ma'am. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Very strong words. No mincing of words there at all. But when you look at the Mueller report and you look at the FISA process, you can understand where it's coming from.

utterances.speaker: GOWDY
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, Peter Strzok, who is the lead case agent on this Russia probe, was talking about impeaching Donald Trump before Adam Schiff and Jerry Nadler were.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GOWDY
utterances.sentences: I mean, just let that sink in for a second. The lead agent for the FBI mentioned impeaching Trump before Schiff and Nadler did. And so, then the FBI conducts this defensive briefing, which is really just an interview because they suspected Donald Trump of impropriety. And you got James Comey who thinks impeachment is too good for him. You got John Brennan who thinks he should be in the dust pan of history. You got Andy McCabe who after Comey was fired launched yet another investigation into Trump.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GOWDY
utterances.sentences: Martha, if I were Donald Trump, I would think the FBI was out to get me, too.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes. You know, he also pointed out that when he fired him, it was obviously a huge story. We all covered it. But he felt that it was ultimately the move that saved him. Because he believed that he was eliminating the person at the top who created a culture that was after him, that believed, you know, based on -- essentially on the dossier and some other things around it. But this dossier that was paid for by Hillary Clinton and the DNC used that to create an environment where they believed that they were above board in investigating the president and his campaign. I mean, it is -- it is pretty stunning when you look back at it.

utterances.speaker: GOWDY
utterances.sentences: Yes, I would correct the president's narrative only to this extent. Remember, he replaced Comey with McCabe. I mean, that is hardly --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: That's true.

utterances.speaker: GOWDY
utterances.sentences: -- moving up the draft board. It was only when Chris Wray came in that I think you had in this passionate objective law enforcement centered person. McCabe is -- McCabe was no better than Comey. So, we had to get all the way through --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Well, he got -- he got moved up because it was, you know, I mean, he was sort of the next person available, I guess, at that time.

utterances.speaker: GOWDY
utterances.sentences: Well --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Do you think the culture has changed at the FBI? Because, you know, there's a lot of discussion about what's next. You know, I mean, which phone call, which -- you know, there's already investigations that are continuing into the president's taxes and everything else. But do you think the culture has changed at the top?

utterances.speaker: GOWDY
utterances.sentences: I hope so, Martha. I hope so, and I say that because I don't know. I mean, I haven't talked to Chris Wray since I left Congress.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GOWDY
utterances.sentences: But those of us, you know, Ratcliffe and others who are former federal prosecutors, we're not going to make it as a country if people don't have confidence in the FBI. And it's been a really bad four years with Strzok and McCabe and Baker, and Page, and Comey. I mean, it's been a terrible four years for the world's premier law enforcement agency. I didn't get to watch Chris' testimony this week. I read some articles about it. I think some of my Republican colleagues weren't all that impressed with the changes that Chris has outlined. But we're not going to survive if the American people do not have confidence in the FBI.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes. All right. Trey Gowdy, thank you very much. Good to see you tonight.

utterances.speaker: GOWDY
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Still ahead on the story tonight, Senator Chris Coons with a powerful message about prayer and the president.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Quite a story here. The Chinese physician who was sanctioned after sounding the alarm about coronavirus has died. Following a day of conflicting reports about his health. Chief breaking news correspondent Trace Gallagher has the latest. Hi, Trace.

utterances.speaker: TRACE GALLAGHER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Hi, Martha. This story goes to the very heart of why human rights groups in foreign countries are so skeptical of the information being given by the Chinese government. Back last in December, 34-year-old Dr. Li Wenliang who was an ophthalmologist sent a note on social media to his medical school alumni group warning them and telling them to warn their loved ones that seven patients had been quarantined at the Wuhan central hospital with a respiratory illness that seemed like the SARS virus. Remember, SARS was the outbreak in China that sickened thousands and killed hundreds in 2002, 2003. But the warning Dr. Wenliang sent to his former colleagues was posted online and quickly went viral. That's when the doctor was taken into custody by the Wuhan police where he was reprimanded and required to sign a letter acknowledging that he made false claims. The Chinese government later issued its own statement saying the disease was, quote, "preventable and controllable with no obvious human-to-human transition." Thirteen days later, Dr. Wenliang was having trouble breathing and checked himself in to Wuhan central hospital. But he either wasn't diagnose or we didn't learn he was diagnosed with coronavirus until February 1st when he posted it on social media. Earlier this week, Wenliang did interviews with both the New York Times and CNN, criticizing the Chinese government for not disclosing information about the virus sooner. Then last night, reports began surfacing that Dr. Wenliang had passed away. Hours later, those reports were retracted, saying he was in critical condition. But today, Wuhan central hospital confirmed that Dr. Li Wenliang had passed away. The illness and the death toll from the coronavirus have now surpassed that from SARS. Six hundred thirty-six people have now died. That's according to the Chinese government. Martha?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: It's a tragedy. He was a brave doctor and spoke out --

utterances.speaker: GALLAGHER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: -- when other people weren't. Thank you very much, Trace.

utterances.speaker: GALLAGHER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Good to have you here. So, one senator's message about the power of prayer in a --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Wounds from the impeachment battle still fresh today, they spilled over today at an event intended to bring all sides together. The National Prayer Breakfast. My next guest, a former co-chair of that event, offers a sobering message about faith transcending politics. Writing in the Washington Post, quote, "Prayer is as much about having hope that we will be forgiven as it is about forgiving others. Prayer for me is about witnessing to the possibility of repentance and reconciliation even across the hardest and most bitter divides." Joining me now, Democratic Senator Chris Coons of Delaware. Senator Coons, thank you so much for being here today.

utterances.speaker: SEN. CHRIS COONS, D-DEL.
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Martha.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I know that obviously it's been a busy and difficult week --

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: -- for a lot of Americans and certainly --

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: -- everybody has been strained and you have a lot of things going on in your own life, I know. So, we wish you well on all of that.

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: With regard to your parents. So, give me a little sense of -- you know, one of the things that I thought that was interesting that you brought up was Arthur Brooks' message. Arthur Brooks has been a guest on this show. I think our viewers are familiar with him. But what was his message at the beginning of the breakfast today?

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.sentences: Well, Arthur Brooks was the keynote speaker who shared obviously the podium with President Trump who also addressed the crowd. Arthur Brooks, the title of his remarks was 'love thy enemies.' And he gave a very compelling speech about how Christ calls us not just to civility not just to tolerance but to genuinely open our hearts to and love those who are our opponents, who persecute us, who are our enemies in a very real sense. And it was a funny speech, it was a challenging speech, it was an uplifting speech. And obviously, both Speaker Pelosi and President Trump were in the room and at the dais with him as were dozens of members of Congress both Houses and the cabinet. And one of the things I was proud of about his remarks and how the Republican and Democratic member of the House who co-chair the House prayer breakfast about their remarks was that they showed to our guests at the prayer breakfast today who represent more than 100 countries from around the world, the best of how we are at times able to rise above our differences here in Congress and in the United States.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Let's listen to the president today. Hot off of his acquittal, which obviously he's very relieved and happy about. And here's what he had to say at the breakfast this morning.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I don't like people who use their faith as justification for doing what they know is wrong. Nor do I like people who say I pray for you when they know that that's not so.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So, the bald man, Arthur Brooks at the table there who leaned over to grab a sip of water during that moment may have been reacting in some ways to what the president said. What did you think about that moment? What was it like?

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.sentences: I was uncomfortable. I think it was an unfortunate focus on rejecting the offers of others. Their prayers for him, for the president. I don't know if that was in any way directed at my article or at my having prayed for and with the president three years ago. I suspect it was more focused on the contest of the moment of today. Look, Martha, we all have sharp differences in terms of our politics and our views here in Washington.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.sentences: But the point of the prayer breakfast is not to question each other's faith or to challenge each other but to welcome and to accept the prayers of others and to try to seek some encouragement and uplift.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.sentences: The way the prayer breakfast actually started was President Eisenhower communicated to a group of senators, he said, you know, the White House can be the loneliest house in America. It's a very hard place to bear the burdens of the office. And he asked for a chance to come and pray with senators. And in my editorial in the Post, I reference how three years ago President Trump invited me to travel with him to Dover Air Force Base in Delaware as he welcomed home the remains of Ryan Owens, a navy SEAL who had been killed in Yemen. It was the first combat death of his presidency. And I reflected on how heavy the office must have felt on his shoulders that night as we stood next to each other and a flag draped coffin came out of the back of an American C-17 and his family received his remains for the first time. I'm mindful of how heavy the burden of the office is on any president.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.sentences: And I have prayed for every president and I've done so for President Trump as well.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: And he wrote in that, beautifully in that editorial that you also saw that the moment was impactful for the president as well. That you could see that he was feeling the weight of the burden of that moment and of the presidency. You know, Nancy Pelosi weighed in on this, too, sort of firing back at the president, questioning whether or not he understands prayer. Here's that.

utterances.speaker: PELOSI
utterances.sentences: I don't know if the president understands about prayer or people who do pray. But we do pray for the United States of America, I pray hard for him because he is so off the track of our Constitution, our values, our country.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I mean, you know, I think you just weight for somebody to sort of take the high road here in some of these situations. You know, I just wonder what your reaction is to that. I think prayer is such a personal thing.

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Judging anybody's ability to pray or the way they pray or whether or not they understand prayer just seems over the line.

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.sentences: Well, what I thought was the highlight of the prayer breakfast this morning was when the Republican and Democrat Congressman Suozzi of Long Island and Mueller of Michigan, who are the co-chairs of the House Prayer Breakfast opened in prayer and showed through the dynamic between them just what a warm and genuine relationship they have that they've developed through praying together. Of course, they have differences. Of course, they have political disputes. And so, do many of us. And in the article that I wrote, I try to be clear that I strongly disagree with some of the president's policy priorities. But we can't let that prevent us from being open to each other and seeking to work together. Because honestly, what I hear from Delaware week in and week out, is why can't you guys get along? Why can't you solve our country's problems? We're just coming off a very divisive fight over impeachment. I voted to remove the president. And I could understand how he would feel insulted by that vote. I feel strongly about my having come to the right conclusion. But that still doesn't prevent me from earnestly praying for our country, for my fellow senators and for our leaders, and in particular, our president. And I would hope that out of the spirit of today's breakfast folks who visited us from around the world would get to see some of the positives of how we are able to come together even in the midst of this very difficult and divisive moment.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Well, maybe they did. There's a psalm, 'lean not on thy own understanding' which I think is powerful as well because we all just are doing the best we can in these difficult times and trying to get through it all. Thank you so much, Senator Coons.

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Martha.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Good to see you tonight as always. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So that is The Story of Thursday, February 6th, 2020. A busy day in Washington and all across the country. "The Story" will continue tomorrow and we'll be back here tomorrow for a Friday. We'll see you then at 7 o'clock. Coming up next, though, Tucker Carlson takes it away from Washington, D.C. Thanks for joining me tonight, everybody. We'll see you back here on The Story tomorrow at 7. Have a great night. Content and Programming Copyright 2020 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED.
